message.content: Consider a geometric series with first term $a$ and common ratio $r$. Recall that the sum of the first $n$ terms of the geometric series is given by the formula $$S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r}.$$ In this particular series, we have $a=1$ and $r=1/3$. We want to find the sum of the entire series, so we let $n$ approach infinity. Since $|r| < 1$, the term $r^n$ approaches 0 as $n$ becomes arbitrarily large, so we have $$\lim_{n \to \infty } S_n = \lim_{n \to \infty } \frac{1(1-(1/3)^n)}{1-1/3} = \frac{\cancelto{0}{1-\lim_{n \to \infty } (1/3)^n}}{2/3} = \boxed{\frac{3}{2}}.$$
